answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found some resources that might be helpful.
Below I included information on how to handle narrow-banding from the Illinois Municipal League.
http://www.iml.org/page.cfm?key=6912
The International Municipal Signal Association and the International Association of Fire Chiefs partnered to create a Public Safety Guide for Compliance with FCC narrow-banding regulations.
http://siec.wa.gov/links/files/narrowbanding.pdf
The FCC offers more information on grants and narrow-banding procedures on their website. 
http://transition.fcc.gov/pshs/public-safety-spectrum/narrowbanding.html
I have also included a couple of news stories about how different areas have been approaching narrow-banding changes.
Glens Falls, NY
http://poststar.com/news/local/costly-fcc-rule-requires-municipalities-upgrade-radio-systems/article_e4abf5d6-0e4d-11e1-82d5-001cc4c03286.html
Indiana County, PA
http://www.menafn.com/qn_news_story.asp?storyid=%7Bcb7577fc-9dc3-4455-8f9c-8af26ba0d0f6%7D
Lackawanna County, PA
http://www.timesleader.com/golackawanna/news/Vote_on__21M_county_borrowing_plan_set_for_Nov__9_11-06-2011.html
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

author: Cameron Clapper
text: Being that new narrowbanding requirements will go into effect as of January 1, 2013 the city of Whitewater Wisconsin will be taking steps to meet those requirements in the upcoming year.  My question is for municipalities that have either already updated, or are in the process of updating their systems.  How was your municipality able to meet those requirements?  What vendors were used, and were you able to work with surrounding municipalities/counties when purchasing new equipment and updating existing radios?
title: New Narrowbanding Requirements
